A process or set of rules to be followed in calculations or other problem-solving operations, especially by a computer describes an A: Troubleshooting problem B: Set of inputs C: Algorithm D: Computer program

To make this algorithm functional, which step would you add to step 4?Scan to find the smallest numberSet to 0 in the index in the output arrayRemove that number from the input array __________________________________________ A: Repeat steps 1-3, but subtract the total from the numbers summated B: Print output in the correct order C: Divide the array by the index, print the array output D: Repeat steps 1-3, but add 1 to the index number for each loop
quizSrc.definition: Repeat steps 1-3, but add 1 to the index number for each loop

quizSrc.term: Take input, get output, use output on next input is an example of a learning algorithm A: True B: False
Learning algorithms require large datasets, which means storing identifying information about users A: True B: False

A: Feedback loop B: Large dataset C: Learning algorithm D: False dichotomy

Are anonymous datasets truly anonymous? A: Yes, thanks to privacy regulations B: Yes, thanks to machine learning randomness algorithms C: No, due to lacking regulations D: No, due to combining data and re-identification
quizSrc.definition: No, due to combining data and re-identification

quizSrc.term: Which of the following best describes what an algorithm is? quizSrc.definition: A recipe that a computer uses to solve problems

A: Scan to find the smallest number Set to 0 in the index in the output array Remove that number from the input array Repeat steps 1-3, but add 1 to the index number for each loop B: Scan to find the smallest number Set the length of the array in the index in the output array Remove that number from the input Repeat steps 1-3, but add 1 to the index number for each loop C: Scan to find the smallest number Set to 0 in the index in the output array Remove that number from the input array D: Scan to find the largest number Set to 0 in the index in the output array Remove that number from the input array Repeat steps 1-3, but add 1 to the index number for each loop
quizSrc.definition: Scan to find the smallest number Set to 0 in the index in the output array Remove that number from the input array Repeat steps 1-3, but add 1 to the index number for each loop

quizSrc.term: What's the difference between a basic and learning algorithm? A: A basic algorithm takes an input and gets an output, while a learning algorithm takes multiple inputs and gets multiple outputs B: An basic algorithm takes an input and gets an output, while a learning algorithm uses the output on the next input C: A basic algorithm takes an input, gets an output, while a learning algorithm takes multiple inputs and gets multiple outputs D: A basic algorithm takes an input, while a learning algorithm takes an input and gets an output

quizSrc.definition: Even if you haven't shared an direct datapoint about yourself, with enough related datapoints the algorithm can make an educated guess with alarming accuracy

quizSrc.definition: To adjust the model based on a subset of data, optimizing for a lower error rate

quizSrc.term: When building a predictive model, what is the goal of the deployment phase? quizSrc.definition: The percentage of predictions that don't match actual outcomes

The optimistic view of general ai could be accurately summarized as ai as a ____ A: Peace-keeping tool B: Human right C: Weapon D: Utility
The pessimist view of general ai references a scenario in which advancement is _____ A: Creating ai for all governments B: Impossible C: Winner take all D: A potential extinction event
An ethical general purpose ai must _____ while not harming the safety of humanity A: Keep those in power responsible B: Be 100% accurate C: Benefit as many people as possible D: Not enact hate
quizSrc.definition: Benefit as many people as possible

quizSrc.term: "companies have an obligation to their shareholders" is part of a view that sees artificial intelligence as A: An overall good for humanity, no matter the consequences B: A harmful tool that will bring about the end of capitalism C: Just another tool that accelerates research, like online advertising D: A gimmick for enterprises, unless general intelligence is achieved
quizSrc.definition: Just another tool that accelerates research, like online advertising

quizSrc.term: An unintended negative outcome of programming a broad goal into general intelligence is known as A: Perverse instantiation B: Artificial sanctification C: An ethical dilemma D: An enduring output
True or false: the definition of fairness is "just treatment without bias and contempt" A: True B: False

Statistical parity as a fairness goal makes the most sense when A: Distributing randomly, ex. tickets B: Distributing by merit, ex. loans C: Distributing by gender, ex. tickets D: Distributing by error rate, ex. loans
Error rate parity means an equal chance of A: Outcomes for each group B: Prediction rate for each group C: Mistakes made for each group D: Approval for each group

If you know one group is misrepresented in merit by training data, one way to ensure fairness is to A: Delete that group's data from the dataset B: Protect a different group C: Create a separate threshold for that group D: Reboot the training data
quizSrc.definition: Create a separate threshold for that group

quizSrc.term: True or false: fairness in machine learning cannot protect all individuals within protected groups from harm A: True B: False
Our goal in machine learning fairness is to minimize _______ as long as _______ is obtained A: Accuracy issues, unfairness B: Unfairness, equality C: Error rates, parity D: Equality, error rates
Fairness is best defined as just treatment without __________ A: Prejudice and favoritism B: Discrimination and prejudice C: Bias and contempt D: Favoritism or discrimination
Which type of fairness would make sense when dividing tickets evenly between groups? A: Equality of prediction rate B: Statistical parity C: Equality of false positives D: Error rate parity
Which type of fairness fails to address merit while maintaining accuracy? A: Error rate parity B: Statistical parity C: Equality of prediction rate D: Equality of false positives
A model that prioritizes equality on the outputs uses A: Equality of prediction rate B: Equality of assignment rate C: Error rate parity D: Statistical parity
Fairness in machine learning can protect groups from bias, but can still harm A: Individuals within those groups B: Future models C: Researchers D: Training datasets

A goal of a fair model's accuracy standards is to A: Minimize the quality metrics as long as the quantity metrics aren't affected B: Minimize the error rate as long as the training data isn't affected C: Minimize the error rate as long as parity is obtained D: Minimize the fairness score as long as the error rate isn't affected
quizSrc.definition: Minimize the error rate as long as parity is obtained

quizSrc.term: A model that makes more mistakes by moving its decision threshold down 40% of its worthiness metric will be potentially A: Fairer but less accurate B: Less fair but more accurate C: More accurate and fairer D: Less accurate and less fair

If one group comprises the majority of the training data, they will skew the dataset and give the model A: More fairness for that group B: Less fairness for that group C: More confidence about that group D: Less confidence about that group

If we know one group's worthiness score has been artificially inflated, one solution for fairness is to A: Remove that group from the dataset B: Add the inflation to the other data C: Balance the error rate by prioritizing the other group D: Creating separate decision thresholds for each group
quizSrc.definition: Creating separate decision thresholds for each group

quizSrc.term: An unfair model will by nature A: Try to balance groups automatically B: Optimize for making the most errors C: Optimize for making the fewest mistakes D: Optimize for making the fewest decisions
quizSrc.definition: Optimize for making the fewest mistakes

quizSrc.term: True or false: it is practical to protect all possible subgroups in predictive modeling A: True B: False

In machine learning, a pareto curve helps us A: Highlight the inequality in our model B: Pick an optimal threshold for accuracy and error rate C: Pick an optimal tradeoff between fairness and accuracy D: Select which model will give the best results
quizSrc.definition: Pick an optimal tradeoff between fairness and accuracy

quizSrc.term: True or false: a blind attribute model protects group fairness by not including group membership in predictions A: True B: False
An adversarial algorithm is _______________ to identify weaknesses in black box models A: Given no data B: Purposefully biased C: Purposefully fair D: Trained with large datasets
True or false: our analysis revealed that word2vec is not a black box model A: True B: False
Which step in the fairness process would be most appropriate to introduce an auditing model? A: Sub-processing B: Pre-processing C: Post-processing D: In-processing

A state where resources cannot be reallocated to make one individual better off without making at least one individual worse off is known as a A: Pareto efficiency B: Prisoner's dilemma C: Boron letter D: Aggregate curve

In machine learning, what do we plot on the x,y axis to determine a pareto curve? A: Error rate, rejection rate B: Rejection rate, false-positive rate C: Rejection rate, subgroup fairness rate D: Error rate, true positive rate

Why is it impractical to protect all possible subgroups in predictive models? A: Individuals do not need protection from predictive models B: Fairness scores won't be high enough to be reasonable C: Accuracy will be lowered beyond a reasonable rate D: There won't be enough data to reflect each subgroup
quizSrc.definition: Accuracy will be lowered beyond a reasonable rate

quizSrc.term: A model that equalizes the number of mistakes it makes for each subgroup to reduce harm is deciding on A: Equality of false negatives B: Equality of training data C: Equality of prediction bias D: Equality of true outcomes

A _________ model can still be unfair even though it won't explicitly know which groups are being inputted into the system A: Single attribute B: Biased training C: Blind attribute D: False-negative optimized

What tools do researchers have to evaluate the fairness of existing black box models? A: Evaluate inputs, evaluate data B: Change training data, evaluate outputs C: Change inputs, evaluate outputs D: Change inputs, evaluate training data
A "purposefully biased" algorithm used to identify unfair attributes is known as A: A predictive model B: An aggregate algorithm C: A discriminatory algorithm D: An adversarial algorithm
In presenting an audit report, a researcher would A: Prevent the model from launching B: De-bias the results C: Score the weight of input attributes on output D: Re-train the model
quizSrc.definition: Score the weight of input attributes on output

quizSrc.term: In fixing the word2vec model, we have an advantage over a traditional black box model in that A: We can decide which inputs to use B: We have access to the training data C: We can see the decision-making model D: We can generate a fairness score
quizSrc.definition: We have access to the training data

quizSrc.term: An auditing model is an example of a ______ bias mitigation method A: Sub-processing B: Pre-processing C: Post-processing D: In-processing
True or false: the no free lunch theorem states that we cannot have fair models without giving up something else A: True B: False

Which of the following is a good example of sample bias? A: Your model is trained to recognize pets, but you only give it photos of dogs B: Your model is trained to avoid bias, but it contains no samples of that bias C: Your model is broken because it cannot sample the right attribute D: Your model is designed to give loans to those who need it, but it is trained with unfair data
quizSrc.definition: Your model is trained to recognize pets, but you only give it photos of dogs

quizSrc.term: When cleaning/parsing data removes a potentially important attribute, that is referred to as A: Confirmation bias B: Automation bias C: Exclusion bias D: Observer bias
Labeling outputs made by predictive models can avoid which feedback issue? A: Predictive loop bias B: Fairness score bias C: Re-training bias D: Sample bias
True or false: recommendation engines are not as susceptible to feedback bias due to their constraints on data inputs A: True B: False

A "best response" in game theory is when A: A user chooses the least fair option B: A user leaves a group setting to pursue individual goals C: A user has no choice but to follow the group dynamic to benefit D: A user comes up with the best response from the group
quizSrc.definition: A user has no choice but to follow the group dynamic to benefit

quizSrc.term: The __________ theorem states that all models have the same error rate when averaged over all possible data generating distributions. A: Pareto efficiency B: Zero handouts C: No free lunch D: Biased aggregate

As a cognitive bias, humans see lack of context/meaning around a piece of information and tend to A: Fill in gaps with existing knowledge B: Seek authority figures C: Disagree with their previous beliefs D: Use biased sources of research
quizSrc.definition: Fill in gaps with existing knowledge

quizSrc.term: When your collected data doesn't accurately reflect the full environment, you're experiencing A: Exclusion bias B: Prejudice bias C: Sample bias D: Observer bias
The tendency to only seek attributes in existing collected data is known as A: Exclusion bias B: Observer bias C: Prejudice bias D: Availability bias

An example of automation bias is A: Using new data over existing data B: Using parsed twitter data over parsed facebook data C: Using scraped twitter data over survey data D: Using biased survey data instead of parsed survey data
quizSrc.definition: Using scraped twitter data over survey data

quizSrc.term: A ________ is when a model is validated by it's own influence on predictions A: Dataset scrub B: False prediction set C: Self-fulfilling prediction D: Training set error

One way to avoid feedback loops in machine learning is to A: Scrub datasets after each decision B: Investigate exclusion bias C: Destroy previous training data D: Label outputs to prevent re-training bias
quizSrc.definition: Label outputs to prevent re-training bias

quizSrc.term: Dating algorithms become biased mostly through offering users _________ A: Different ways to match with users B: Unlimited matches per day C: Collaborative filtering D: Access to separate data models
Predictive loops in marketplace models like dating apps are especially susceptible to bias due to A: Marketplace forces B: Fairness quotients C: Short feedback cycles D: Engagement levels

Game theory states that outcomes that are best for _____ can be obscured by outcomes best for ______ A: The group, the individual B: The dataset, the model C: The model, the individual D: The group, the dataset
A dataset column that cannot directly identify, like zip code, is called a A: Quasi-identifiable column B: Sensitive column C: Non-sensitive column D: Personally identifiable column
True or false: k-anonymity protects users from all privacy violations A: True B: False
Which of the following is an example of partially obfuscated data? A: 60-70 years old B: Had a stroke C: 65 years old D: 94103
True or false: a non-sensitive column can endanger user privacy A: True B: False

Why is it important to limit precise outputs in a predictive model? A: It removes the datasets in danger of violating privacy B: It can help users make better decisions C: It can help limit adversarial attacks D: It limits the ability of researchers
quizSrc.definition: It can help limit adversarial attacks

quizSrc.term: Where is a perturbed input used? A: When building a model B: To increase public dataset awareness C: To identify an error in a machine learning model D: To observe differing outputs

A dataset attribute that is not identifiable but constitutes data about the individual that needs to be protected is known as a A: Quasi-identifier B: Explicitly private column C: Non-sensitive column D: Sensitive column

K-anonymity in a dataset is achieved when each individual cannot be A: Harmed from datasets with k individuals belonging to the sensitive class B: Hidden from a quasi-identifier column as long as k individuals belong C: Reidentified in k datasets D: Distinguished from at least k individuals who are also in the dataset
quizSrc.definition: Distinguished from at least k individuals who are also in the dataset

quizSrc.term: A major downside to k-anonymity is that re-identification is possible with A: Multiple datasets B: Sensitive columns C: Database leaks D: Expanding k values

A hospital dataset protects whether an individual has had either a stroke, heart attack, or staph infection. the individual may still be harmed via dataset A: Group inclusion B: Security issues C: K-anonymity D: Privacy columns

A non-sensitive column may become sensitive or even identifiable when viewed through the lens of A: Community privacy violations B: Societal privacy violations C: Algorithmic privacy violations D: Human privacy violations

An example of a public dataset at risk of an algorithmic privacy violation is the A: Google search view dataset B: Fidelity bank lending dataset C: Stanford hospital dataset D: Google maps satellite view dataset
The netflix prize privacy scandal is an example of reidentification through A: Multiple datasets B: Database leaks C: K-anonymity D: Sensitive columns
The nature of a predictive model may reveal ___________ A: The researchers behind it B: The data it is trained on C: The algorithm's bias D: The ethics of the individual inputs
quizSrc.definition: The data it is trained on

quizSrc.term: An adversarial model relies on using __________ to observe different outputs A: Algorithm detection B: Perturbed inputs C: Sensitive columns D: Pressure inputs
One way to counter a potential adversarial algorithm is by A: Changing the datasets B: Limiting precise outputs C: Banning model updates D: Improving model transparency

Which of the following is not a recommended security practice in machine learning? A: Create a chain of command B: Ensure that all team members/stakeholders have a basic understanding of security C: Perform threat modeling D: Enact a sound data governance structure
True or false: data minimization is the concept of shrinking datasets to only what is required to fulfill a general purpose A: True B: False
A model working at 95% with 100k rows of data and 97% with 500k rows is an example of A: Dataset limitations B: Accuracy issues C: Diminishing returns D: Sensitive columns
True or false: global differential privacy is added after data is collected A: True B: False
Randomized response in local differential privacy gives its users which of the following? A: Plausible deniability B: Global privacy C: K-anonymity D: Fairness guarantees
In reverse-engineering a double coin flip differential model, what would be the amount of falsified "yes/no" responses in our dataset? A: 75% B: 50% C: 25% D: 100%

Which of the following is a recommended security practice for machine learning datasets? A: Ensure your team is full of different perspectives B: Perform threat modeling with beneficial algorithms C: Create a chain of command D: Enact a sound data governance structure
quizSrc.definition: Enact a sound data governance structure

quizSrc.term: The data minimization principle requires that you limit data collection to only what is __________ A: Necessary for differential privacy B: Needed to have k-anonymity C: Required to fulfill a specific purpose D: Optional for a chain of command
quizSrc.definition: Required to fulfill a specific purpose

quizSrc.term: Delete unused data __________ is a method of data minimization A: Early and often B: Before modeling C: After fairness preparations D: Before threat modeling

Gdpr states that "personal data shall be adequate, relevant and __________ in relation to the purpose or purposes for which they are processed." A: Not excessive B: Highly specified C: Broadly applicable D: Thoroughly vetted

What can be learned from a predictive model should not change if the _________ is either included or excluded in the training set A: Dataset filter B: Individual's data C: Model fairness score D: Biased dataset
Differential privacy works by adding what to a dataset? A: Filters B: Fairness scoring C: K-anonymity D: Noise

If a coin is flipped, which of the following would ensure "yes/no" data is private while still remaining useful? A: Heads for true answer, tails for random answer B: Heads for yes, tails for no C: Heads for fake answer, tails for true answer D: Heads for random answer, tails for yes
quizSrc.definition: Heads for true answer, tails for random answer

quizSrc.term: At which level of differential privacy is the outcome secured from even the people collecting answers? A: K-anonymous B: Premium C: Local D: Global

Plausible deniability refers to the ability of the individual to ______ A: Remove themselves from a machine learning dataset B: Claim their score was randomized response C: Express their participation in a study D: Doubt the results of a study
quizSrc.definition: Claim their score was randomized response

quizSrc.term: In reverse-engineering a double coin flip differential model, what would be the amount of truthful "yes/no" responses in our dataset? A: 50% B: 25% C: 100% D: 75%
True or false: a glass box model is traditionally preferred by businesses A: True B: False
An ethical model will be more fair and explainable, at the expense of ________ A: Recruiting B: Accuracy C: Dataset collection D: Privacy
Explainable models can provide _________, which look very similar to auditing models A: Model renderings B: Dataset fairness graphs C: Attribute weight charts D: Privacy protection

Which of the following is a strategy to improve group outcomes using game theory? A: Fairness-enforcing methods B: Explainable recommendation systems C: Privacy-enforcing algorithms D: Ethical predictive sets
True or false: glass box models allow agents to re-run them A: True B: False
A differentially private search algorithm would add some ______ at the expense of _______ A: Noise, privacy B: Accuracy, noise C: Noise, accuracy D: Data points, privacy
Ethical models are _________ A: Precise, explainable, and fair B: Precise, explainable, and private C: Accurate, methodical, and fair D: Accurate, explainable, and fair
A _____ model is preferred by businesses because they see less competition as a benefit A: Black box B: Fair C: Ethical D: Precise
One benefit of an explainable model is A: Privacy is preserved B: Recruiting leverage C: The model is more accurate D: Less competition
The strava dataset example illustrates that while differential privacy can protect individuals, it can still harm _______ A: Certain individuals B: Those outside the dataset C: Groups D: Researchers
The explainable ai movement states that cooperation between agents, in this case, algorithms and humans, depends on which of the following? A: Trust B: Privacy C: Human rights D: Competition
A benefit of glass-box models is that if an attribute is skewing the fairness of a decision, a human agent may choose to A: Alert the team B: Trust it C: Ignore it D: Re-run the algorithm without it
_____ algorithms are a challenge to explainable ai, as their complexity makes it difficult to weigh attribute importance A: Explainable B: Ethical C: Deep learning D: Malicious
When used in recommendation engines, explainable algorithms can help answer the question of ____ A: How? B: Who? C: Why? D: What?
Group outcomes being improved through explainable recommendation systems is an example of using _______ to modify outcomes A: Competition B: Game theory C: Privacy D: Government
A major limitation of using explainable, adjustable algorithms is that users tend to make _____ decisions A: Malicious B: Selfish C: Socially conscious D: Private
